How to access UKB data on Rosalind

Source: vignettes/kcl-ukb-access.Rmd
kcl-ukb-access.Rmd

Note. This document is only useful for UKB-approved KCL reasearchers and their collaborators, with an account on the Rosalind HPC cluster.

A UKB project corresponds to a single UKB application; a study fits within the scope of a project, and typically corresponds to a single publication. Each project potentially includes many studies. Project directories on Rosalind have roughly the same internal structure, including subdirectories for raw, decrypted and derived data. To access data for a particular UKB-approved project, KCL researchers and collaborators need to be named investigators/ collaborators on that particular project. Phenotype data in a project is accessed through the ukbkings R package. Genotype data is accessed via a symbolic link in the user’s directory, once permission has been granted.

For security reasons, the layout of directories on Rosalind and specific path names are described in lustre_storage.doc, on Basecamp (Team: UK Biobank > Docs & Files).


Pre-requisites

You must have an account on Rosalind (contact Rosalind support), and access to the phenotype data in a specific project directory. You will need separate permission to access to the genotype data. For access to phenotype and genotype data contact ken.b.hanscombe@kcl.ac.uk.


ukbkings installation

To retrieve your study specific data, start an interactive cluster session with sufficient virtual memory to manipulate the +25GB decrypted project data.

qrsh -l h_vmem=30G


Navigate to your Rosalind user directory, run R, and install the R package ukbkings.

devtools::install_github("kenhanscombe/ukbkings", dependencies = TRUE)


Alternatively, create a conda environment from ukbkings-env.yml.

wget https://github.com/kenhanscombe/ukbkings/blob/master/ukbkings-env.yml

conda env create -f ukbkings-env.yml

source activate ukbkings-env
# inspect/ retrieve UKB data (see below)
source deactivate ukbkings-env

The environment created, ukbkings-env, includes R 3.7, the ukbkings package, and all essential R packages (based on this setup), as well as Python 3.7 and Snakemake 1.X.

Aside: It is considered good practice to have a self-contained environment for each analysis, with software installation and dependencies handled by an environment manager like conda. You may find it useful to use this environment for your phenotype analysis.


Phenotype data

To use the example data bundled with the package

proj_dir <- system.file("testdata", package = "ukbkings")


Field-to-name data

To get a dataframe of project fields

# library(ukbkings)

proj_fields <- bio_field(proj_dir)
head(proj_fields)
#>     basket     field                                               name
#> 1 ukb12345     f.eid                                                eid
#> 2 ukb12345  f.31.0.0                                        sex_f31_0_0
#> 3 ukb12345  f.54.0.0               uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_0_0
#> 4 ukb12345  f.54.1.0               uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_1_0
#> 5 ukb12345  f.54.2.0               uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_2_0
#> 6 ukb12345 f.189.0.0 townsend_deprivation_index_at_recruitment_f189_0_0
#>               ukb_type  r_type
#> 1             Sequence integer
#> 2 Categorical (single) integer
#> 3 Categorical (single) integer
#> 4 Categorical (single) integer
#> 5 Categorical (single) integer
#> 6           Continuous  double
#>                                                                path
#> 1 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 2 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 3 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 4 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 5 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 6 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv


You will need to create a file in your user directory that contains the fields you require, one per line. You can use a pager to manually search through the available fields and add these to a text file, one per line.

page(proj_fields, method = "print")


Or, as proj_fields is a dataframe, you can use regular expressions to search the field or name columns, then manually add these to

proj_fields %>% 
  filter(str_detect(field, "54"))
#>     basket    field                                 name
#> 1 ukb12345 f.54.0.0 uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_0_0
#> 2 ukb12345 f.54.1.0 uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_1_0
#> 3 ukb12345 f.54.2.0 uk_biobank_assessment_centre_f54_2_0
#>               ukb_type  r_type
#> 1 Categorical (single) integer
#> 2 Categorical (single) integer
#> 3 Categorical (single) integer
#>                                                                path
#> 1 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 2 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv
#> 3 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv


proj_fields %>% 
  filter(str_detect(name, "3"))
#>     basket       field                                           name
#> 1 ukb12345    f.31.0.0                                    sex_f31_0_0
#> 2 ukb12345  f.6142.0.3            current_employment_status_f6142_0_3
#> 3 ukb12345  f.6142.1.3            current_employment_status_f6142_1_3
#> 4 ukb12345  f.6142.2.3            current_employment_status_f6142_2_3
#> 5 ukb12345 f.21003.0.0 age_when_attended_assessment_centre_f21003_0_0
#> 6 ukb12345 f.21003.1.0 age_when_attended_assessment_centre_f21003_1_0
#> 7 ukb12345 f.21003.2.0 age_when_attended_assessment_centre_f21003_2_0
#>                 ukb_type  r_type
#> 1   Categorical (single) integer
#> 2 Categorical (multiple) integer
#> 3 Categorical (multiple) integer
#> 4 Categorical (multiple) integer
#> 5                Integer integer
#> 6                Integer integer
#> 7                Integer integer
#>                                                                path
#> 1 /Users/ken/Documents/projects/ukbkings/inst/testdata/ukb12345.csv

Categorical level codes


Selecting a subset of fields


UKB showcase and catalogues

Catalogues are listings of contents of the UKB showcase. There are 5 catalogues:

  • fields
  • categories
  • returns
  • resources
  • schema


  1. Fields

List all variables, or columns in the phenotype data.


  1. Categories

The Category Listings group data into related sets: 14 Recommended, 247 Origin, 12 Core, 9 Specialist, and 3 Miscellaneous categories. (Note. Individual fields are always at least 1 Origin category, and may be in none, one, or more categories of the others)


  1. Returns

List returned datasets.


  1. Resources

This is a list of information relating to particular categories, processes, topics or groups of fields. The full Resource Catalogue is divided into 169 documents, 196 datasets, 820 graphics, 9 videos. (Note. this takes a minute to load.)


  1. Schema

List meta-information about the showcase.


Guides and resources

For primary care data, see Section 5: Record-level hospital inpatient data and primary care (GP) data

Other

  1. Ingres 10.2 SQL reference guide

The relational database management system used by the UKB to hold “record level” information.
